div.p: CCCC MS 210 contains the unique copy of William Worcester's Itineraria. William Worcester (1415-1480/85), a servant of Sir John Fastolf, wrote the Itineraria in note form during a series of journeys he undertook throughout southern and western England between 1478 and 1480, and the manuscript must date from this period. The text's eclectic mixture of local history, biography and geography reflect a lively and curious mind. How this manuscript came into Parker's possession is unknown, and it has been suggested that the codex was another bequest to the college by Henry Aldrich (Fellow 1569-79, d. 1593) (see CCCC MS 208). However, the presence of Parker's characteristic red chalk in the volume and the existence of a partial transcript of the text in CCCC MS 101 must refute that claim. Instead, it is probable that Parker acquired the manuscript shortly before his death, after the composition of his Register, CCCC MS 575, which contains no reference to this manuscript.
